intro: Rubus hamiltonii, commonly known as Hamilton's blackberry, is a species of bramble native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black in color. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forests and along stream banks. Botanically, it belongs to the Rosaceae family and is closely related to other bramble species.
